unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Your Guide to the Film Fest Scene
normalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Your Guide to the Film Fest Scene

unnormalised: Hey folks! Ever feel like the usual Friday night movie at PVR just isn’t cutting it? Craving something more than the latest Salman Khan action flick (no offense, Bhai!)? Then you, my friend, are ready for the wild and wonderful world of film festivals!
normalised: Hey folks! Ever feel like the usual Friday night movie at P V R just isn’t cutting it? Craving something more than the latest Salman Khan action flick (no offense, Bhai!)? Then you, my friend, are ready for the wild and wonderful world of film festivals!

unnormalised: Think of film festivals as like, a mela (fair) for movie buffs. But instead of jalebis and ferris wheels, you get thought-provoking documentaries, indie darlings that might just blow your mind, and the chance to rub shoulders with upcoming directors and actors. Seriously cool, right?
normalised: Think of film festivals as like, a mela (fair) for movie buffs. But instead of jalebis and ferris wheels, you get thought-provoking documentaries, indie darlings that might just blow your mind, and the chance to rub shoulders with upcoming directors and actors. Seriously cool, right?

unnormalised: India's got a vibrant scene. The International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa is a massive one, pulling in entries from all over the globe. But you also get smaller, super cool festivals like the Mumbai Film Festival (MAMI), which showcases some incredible talent. Plus, loads of regional festivals celebrate cinema in languages like Tamil, Bengali, and Marathi.
normalised: India's got a vibrant scene. The International Film Festival of India (I F F I) in Goa is a massive one, pulling in entries from all over the globe. But you also get smaller, super cool festivals like the Mumbai Film Festival (M A M I), which showcases some incredible talent. Plus, loads of regional festivals celebrate cinema in languages like Tamil, Bengali, and Marathi.

unnormalised: Why should you bother shelling out Rs. 500-1000 for a pass (or more, depending on the fest)? Firstly, you see films you *won't* find anywhere else. These aren't your typical multiplex blockbusters. Secondly, the atmosphere is electric! Q&As with filmmakers, discussions, and after-parties – it's a total immersion experience. You might even bump into Anurag Kashyap grabbing a chai!

These aren't your typical multiplex blockbusters. Secondly, the atmosphere is electric! Q and A's with filmmakers, discussions, and after-parties – it's a total immersion experience. You might even bump into Anurag Kashyap grabbing a chai!

unnormalised: Beyond the glitz and glam, film festivals are important for the industry. They give indie filmmakers a platform, help discover new talent, and foster conversations about important social issues. Plus, they are a fun way to discover new cultures and perspectives through the magic of cinema.
normalised: Beyond the glitz and glam, film festivals are important for the industry. unnormalised: So, ditch the Netflix binge this weekend and check out what film festivals are happening near you! You might just discover your next favourite filmmaker, or at least have some killer stories to tell your friends at the next adda. Remember to check online listings for dates, locations (sometimes they even have free screenings at places like Film Bhavan!) and ticket info. Happy watching!
